Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Individual recognition and long-term memory of third-party relationships in a social bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
There is mounting evidence that the evolution of intelligence is primarily driven by the need to navigate complex social relationships. However, the way in which a species' social system influences developing intelligence is less well understood. While it is known that some animals are aware of the relationships between individuals other than themselves, previous studies have concentrated on short-term knowledge about relationships within a single social group. This narrow focus limits the inferences that can be drawn about how different social systems shape intelligence. This project will test whether acorn woodpeckers can remember the relationships between others for years, an ability that has not been investigated in any non-human species. Acorn woodpeckers are a group-living bird in which relatives maintain a relationship even after years of separation, and kin who no longer live together may act as allies in times of conflict. Thus, if acorn woodpeckers can recognize and remember their neighbors' kin for years, they could benefit by keeping track of competitors' allies. This study aims to identify whether they have this ability. The project will create paid positions for two field assistants and several undergraduates will be mentored and learn transferable skills by assisting in data collection and analysis. The investigators will also continue their scientific outreach and education efforts with youth from under-served communities. By improving scientific understanding of the relationship between sociality and cognition, this project could provide perspective on the evolution of intelligence in general.

Technical Abstract:
The goal of this project is to expand our understanding of social cognition by testing the hypothesis that acorn woodpeckers can remember the relationships between others for at least two years. The investigators will create playback stimuli that simulate two birds calling in unison, which acorn woodpeckers only do naturally with current or former members of their own group. Woodpeckers will then receive playbacks of the following simulated vocal exchanges: 1) two related birds who formerly lived together two years ago, 2) two related birds who never lived together, and 3) two unrelated birds who never lived together. In all cases, the callers will be unrelated to the subject. If acorn woodpeckers remember the relationships between birds that lived together two years ago, they should recognize Stimulus 1 as being more socially congruent than 2 and 3, and should thus exhibit a longer response latency to Stimulus 1, indicating less violation of expectation. If they recognize the relationship between callers via an acoustic cue of relatedness rather than by memory, they should show a longer response latency to both Stimuli 1 and 2 compared to 3. This work will also provide relevant training and mentoring to undergraduate students. Results will be communicated to the scientific community through publications and the general non-scientific community through outreach efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project we investigated how acorn woodpeckers, a highly social bird, use vocalizations to extract complex social information about other individuals. We first conducted a field experiment on vocal recognition in which we exposed wild acorn woodpeckers to the call of a current member of their group, the call of a former member of their group, and the call of an outsider. Subjects tended to respond more aggressively to the calls of outsiders than to the calls of current or former group members, although this was not statistically significant. However, we unexpectedly found that subjects responded differently to the calls of living and dead former group members. This provides some of the first experimental evidence that animals know which of their previous social affiliates are still alive.

We then conducted a second experiment to investigate what acorn woodpeckers know about the relationships between other individuals. Like many social animals, acorn woodpeckers maintain relationships with some of their former group members after dispersal, but it is unknown if any animal can recognize such “long-distance” relationships between others. We presented woodpeckers with pairs of calls that simulated two individuals vocalizing together, which acorn woodpeckers normally only do with their social affiliates. In some cases the two callers currently lived in the same group as each other, in some cases they shared a “long-distance” relationship with one another, and in some cases they had no relationship at all. In all cases both callers were not from the same group as the subject. Subjects were expected to react more quickly (indicating greater surprise) if they did not recognize the relationship between the callers. We found that females, but not males, responded as if they recognized both short-distance and long-distance relationships between others. Our results provide the first evidence that an animal can infer the relationships between third parties by observing them interact with one another, even when the third parties in question do not live in the same social group. 

Taken together, the results of our two experiments add to scientific understanding of how the social environment may shape the evolution of intelligence. Acorn woodpeckers live in a society in which long-term alliances with relatives and knowledge about the members of other groups are important for reproductive success, which has likely contributed to the evolution of the complex cognitive abilities that we discovered in this species. Our results pave the way for future studies to investigate what other animals know about members of other groups, and whether there are certain social structures common to species with this type of cognitive ability. 

As part of this project, co-PI M. Pardo hired and mentored two field assistants, both of whom plan to go on to attend graduate school in biology. M. Pardo presented some of the results of this work at the 2018 meeting of the International Society for Behavioral Ecology, and also engaged in several scientific outreach efforts related to the project. M. Pardo presented the research and helped conduct mist-netting demonstrations for two groups of underrepresented minority students who visited our field site: a group of high-school students and a group of university undergraduates. M. Pardo also designed and taught a mini-course on animal communication to a 4thgrade class in Ithaca, NY as part of the GRASSHOPR outreach program at Cornell University.
